title: Which team will win Super Bowl LI?
preds:
Brief Post-Mortem (btw this is for my own personal reference on this site you don't have to read it... I notice I'm the only super-nerd posting so much text but it's for my own personal record): That was painful to watch. My original prediction was 63-37 for the Pats, which turned out good, but I changed my prediction in the middle of the game. My final (before the announcement) prediction was 70-30 Pats when they were advancing the end-zone the final time. Good
My initial prediction was okay. I feel good about the process I used to get there. I also feel comfortable w/ the fact I switched to the Falcons winning, but more on that below. Bad
My lack of knowledge in the game really hurt me tonight. I didn't know about a 2-point conversion until it was about to happen, so I had some higher Atlanta Falcon probabilities because I thought that, even with a touchdown and field goal, the Pats would be 27-28. That meant that a penalty or something would have to happen for them to get that extra point, which I considered was probable not to happen in such a short time frame. So, if I had known about the 2-point conversion (that they could run it in for an extra point instead of kicking it), my probabilities for Falcons would not have been as high b/c I thought the Pats had to make 2 spectacular plays, not 1 to get the 28-28. I am a little upset I changed so much during the game. I understand changing based on the Pats being behind 4 touchdowns is reasonable, but near the end when it was closer to a toss-up, I think I let my adrenaline add more probability where it shouldn't have been. However, I think if I came in the game blind the 3rd quarter, saw the score and Tom Brady + the Pats offense dropping the football, I would've given a higher probability for the Falcons. So I do think my conversion from 63-37 Pats --> 63-->37Falcons was reasonable, and even a 70-30 Falcons was reasonable, but putting it to 90-10 at one point (when I knew little about the game... take case 1: the 2 point conversion thing that ruined my night), especially when this is the first football game I really invested myself in was ambitious and not my best judgment. There IS credit to be given to people who watch these games and have a sense of timing about them. From an outsider view, 2 minutes to comeback seems ridiculous, but it could physically be done. If I had a better base understanding of the sport and its rules, maybe I would've been more conservative. Pat on Back
I think it was ESPN or FOX that had the Falcons at 99% for a bit. I didn't go that far. For that I am pleased. Overall
Good start. I like my process at the beginning. I was weak when it came to updating b/c I didn't know what data is relevant to include in my forecast or not w/ sports except for extreme injuries. I did not update my forecast w/ Matt Ryan getting MVP b/c I figured the weight of that already was told in their #1 offense ranking. My endgame was reasonable... I am comfortable w/ the fact I switched at one point, but need to find a way to be more rational up to the very end and not let my fan excitement get the better of my forecasting. What a game. If you asked me to forecast how awesome Gaga's performance would be, that would've been easier. She did great. Tom Brady took a decade off of my life, but it was an amazing 4th quarter to experience.
ATL suddenly looking like one of league's worst defenses.
Damn son.  Shit went down.  Given the Pats' momentum and the newly tied game, the prediction has been updated.
Tie game in the last minute!

I DID NOT KNOW ABOUT 2 POINT CONVERSIONS WHY!!!!!!! They're going to go into overtime and I think the history of the Pats will support them there. Also, Pats start overtime w/ offense and it's golden-goal style.
Big sack by NE followed by ATL holding penalty, missed NE face mask, and a bad 3rd down throw by Ryan...keeps NE in it. On ATL's D now.
Incredible couple of plays by Atlanta. Their endgame is very strong. We'll see how the Pats do out of this time-out, but the completion rate on the Falcons is making them look very strong.
Patriots are really messing up right now
Updating based on the time left the Pats have to turn this around.
ATL D starting to phone it in a bit with the tackling...three touchdowns in a quarter isn't impossible. And ATL didn't take advantage of NE's muffed onside kick. NE now inside ATL 10.
Going into the fourth quarter 28-9, it would be incredibly unlikely for the Patriots to score 3 td's in the last part of the game.
I knee jerked on Ryan's MVP award as motivation for NE. Almost seems like Brady is trying too hard (and/or under too much pressure from an overachieving ATL defense).
At this point in the game, the Patriots would need a miracle to come back.  The current probability is generous to them.

A 4 touchdown comeback is a hard thing to do. Kuddos to Matt Ryan: I underestimated you and you're going to kill my Brier score because of it. We're seeing the real weight of the #1 offense this game. A postmortem on my prediction to follow after I get over the Gaga performance and how much Tom Brady choked.
Since the start of the game the Falcons seem to have primary control of the game and have points on the board, unlike the patriots

With Falcons up 21, the tides have seriously turned against the Patriots.  Especially with the Falcons starting the second half with the ball, the chances of the Patriots turning this around look increasingly slim.
Patriots will have to make a killing in the second half to win, but crazier things have happened!
Falcons have put up 14 unanswered points by the second quarter...chances of winning are definitely increasing.

With the Falcons up 14-0 in the second quarter, they are quickly increasing their chances of winning.  If they are able to keep the Patriots from scoring before halftime, that will further improve their chances.

Announcement that ATL QB Matt Ryan won NFL MVP is likely to add additional fuel (on top of "Deflategate") to NE QB Tom Brady's motivational fire...still like the upset, but uncertain how Falcons will respond to Super Bowl pressures, while Pats are old hands at this point.

While the Patriots have far more experience at the Super Bowl, especially with Tom Brady and Bill Belichick, not to mention the #1 ranked defense in the league, the Falcons do have a superior offense (#1 ranking) and a solid defense.  However, in marks against the Falcons, Belichick is far more experienced than Dan Quinn, having coached more playoff games than Quinn has ever coached, and Belichick has a 22-3 record against coaches who have not faced him yet (like Quinn).  Nonetheless, given that both teams are #1 ranked gives both a fighting chance at the win, though barring injury or other mishap, the Patriots have a greater chance.
I believe that the Patriots are an all around better team, and they should have little trouble beating the Falcons.
I'm pulling numbers out of the air.

Way too much overlap of people making a big deal of Pat's #1 D and also saying it will be high scoring. So which is it? Atl has an historically good O, I agree with half of the analysis of the game. Yea, the best O will win.
According to the general news, GJP, and 538.com.
14/22 NFL.com analysts predict the Patriots to win

I'm not changing my forecast at this time... I've been following the news on these two teams very closely and don't see any significant shift indicating higher probability towards one or the other. However, I don't feel like that means I should increase my probability for the Pats. Just b/c there's no new info doesn't mean their probability of winning goes up, so just b/c the Falcons haven't put up anything challenging or new doesn't mean that the Pats have a higher likelihood of winning. I guess I'm just trying to write out of my system (and record here for future reference) an innate and incorrect impulse to adjust up for one group or the other as the deadline gets closer. Therefore: I stay at 63-37 until I get information that would make it otherwise.
Have no dog in this fight, but the contrarian in me is forcing me to up my odds on the Falcons. 62% Pats is way out of line with "the line."
its fun to be a contrarian when its against the Patriots

Did not want to stick with 60/40, as this is a very popular choice. Patriots have been to the Superbowl many times before, which gives them an edge from my perspective. They have lost one game all year with Tom Brady. The Patriots were also a top choice to win the Superbowl at the beginning of the year. I can also see the Falcons offense taking off and never looking back, so I am keeping my prediction relatively close.
Falcons are better complete team. Patriots are better coached. Counting on execution from Falcons....but that's fallen apart before
Atlanta is hungry and Matt Ryan is having a MVP year with great receivers.
Updating the FPM model with the playoff performances of the two teams, gives Atlanta 61%

The patriots have better stats for the season and the patriots did not have Tom Brady for the first 4 games of the season. One of the two losses came from those first four games so the Patriots seem to have better odds of winning the super bowl since Tom Brady is playing than the Atlanta Falcons.
The Patriots have been on a 7-win streak, the Falcons have been on a 4-win streak.  The Falcons are more of the underdog in this situation.
This is the probability derived from the bid spread on the game available at Bovada (https://sports.bovada.lv/)

Current line (Pats -3) is almost saying this is a push, and ATL has been covering spreads at a historic rate this season. Possible upset in the making. http://www.nj.com/sports/index.ssf/2017/02/super_bowl_2017_latest_betting_line_odds_on_new_en.html
Pats and Tom Brady are still a powerhouse - in fact Bovada easily has Tom Brady as the favorite to win Super Bowl MVP.  Rarely does the team with the MVP lose the game
Quick early prediction just to get on the board. Will update tomorrow.
Based on reasoning read on GJopen
Not going to dispute the boys from fivethirtyeight. They have an outstanding record!
Betting odds, magazine reviews. Most pick N England as the winner.

The two teams are the Patriots and Falcons. BIASES
I am starting in on this w/ no real prior knowledge of football besides a basic idea of the game and league setup, so that could be a blessing and a curse.
•	Pro: no biases towards which team I "want" to win, no team loyalty.
•	Con: no supporting knowledge of the team's strengths and weaknesses. BASELINE/OUTSIDE
I can form a decent baseline w/ a lifelong devotion to the two teams. I’m going to look at it from a way-outside view, not even considering the specific teams but instead will form a baseline based on the conferences themselves. (For those who don't know: the Superbowl is a clash between the AFC and NFC conference champs.) My baseline: 58.8% towards Pats, based on data since 2000. I chose 2000 as my start point for evaluating data because:
•	the Pat head coach joined the Pats then (the current Falcon head coach joined in 2015… more on him later)
•	the oldest players on both teams started as pros in 2000 (Tom Brady to the Pats, and Matt Bryant to an European league)
I figure data before 2000 will have little effect on this new gen. of football. The AFC (the Pats conference) won 10 Superbowls, while the NFC (the Falcon's conference) won 7 since 2000. 10/17 = 58.8% for the AFC. Will keep the decimal, because 1% can make a big difference according to Tetlock. UNIQUE/INSIDE
Looking inward, I am going to adjust up, since the Pats have a history w/ their current coach of going to the Superbowl and winning. Since 2000, they've won 4 times, and placed 2nd twice. HOWEVER 2 of those wins were in 2004 and 2005, w/ current qback Brady as the qback then. That was over 10 years ago, though they won in 2015 w/ him as a qback. So this may cast some doubt, but he has recently been successful.
# playoff appearances since 2000 for Pats: 14
# playoff appearances since 2000 for Falcons: 7  I’M WRONG (???)
Reasonable doubt is cast w/ the new coach of the Falcons, Dan Quinn. He was hired in 2015 after their other coach was fired for two bad seasons (14th in conference in 2013, 12th in 2014), and in 2015 the Falcons were 7th in their conference (still did not qualify for conference playoffs), and 2nd this year (though still winning NFC champs). This means that pre-2015, it’s hard to compare the Falcons v. Pats track record since this new administration is producing different results from the old one. However, the old one did comparably well in 2012 where they made it to the finals of their conference champs, and they also have had the same starting qb since 2008… so comparing their histories is pretty fair. Though they’ve changed administrations, there were only two big slump years and key players remained constant for almost a decade. Also, the Falcons have the #1 offense in the league (Pats: #3). This is based on NFL stats, and based on the number of points scored per game. Balance this doubt with the fact that the Falcons have #27 defense, with the Pats at #1.  CONCLUSION
58.8% base  adjust up for history of Pat excellence, say history is weighted by 2% = 60.8% Though the Falcons have #1 offense, their defense is not so hot (#27) v. Pat #3 offense and #1 defense. Given this distribution, adjust up for Pats b/c of well-rounded team at to 61.8%. Adjust for confidence: I am under-confident on things I can reason through but am not an expert at (based on distribution from the tests), overconfident for things I think I know like facts. Since I reasoned through this but am not an expert at sports, I am probably more under-confident so will adjust up more to compensate. 61.8 to 62.8 to 63% 63% for Pats. Bring on the 7 layer dip.
According to the general news, GJP, and 538.com.
New England has a super bowl winning quarterback. Lots of Super Bowl experience
Time for the Falcons to get over the hump, and the Patriots to flop....

While the Falcons have a better defense then the Patriots, the Patriots have a better QB in the form of Brady. This game should be high scoring and a relatively close game. However, I believe that the Patriots offensive strategy is slightly better than the Falcons, combined with the Patriots winning four super bowls, shows the coaches have experience.
Patriots are better. But this game should be very high scoring, and that volatility lowers the odds.

Base prediction of 61:39 based on FiveThirtyEight prediction market (I don't know enough about football to dispute the market here). I tweaked the base by 4 (arbitrary) to account for popularity of the Patriots relative to the Falcons, because I figure that some people will let what they want influence what they predict.
Pats are favored but they struggled to protect Brady in the Houston game and their defense is overrated. Going to be a high scoring game, and I think the Pats will pull it out, but it's not a lock.
My prediction is based on hope more than logic. Atlanta is eager to take down a virtual annual participant. Both QBs are amazing,
Atlanta has better team. NE has Belichuk.
I’m just going to punt here: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-nfl-predictions/?ex_cid=rrpromo
Cause the Patriots are dope. (Also while the teams are relatively well matched, particularly looking at the last few games, the Pats are much more experienced playing at this level)
Head coach, QB & team that's been there multiple times.
Vegas odds makers' consensus is New England minus 3, as of 1.25.17
This is the probability derived from the bid spread on the game available at Bovada (https://sports.bovada.lv/football/super-bowl)
According to general news, 538.com, and gjp.com.

The Falcons offense has surmounted better defenses than that of the Patriots. The Patriots will be able to gain consistent ground on the Falcons as well, thereby reducing this contest to one of defense. With the Falcons coming off an aberrant rout of the Packers and in possession of considerable momentum and conviction, I'll give them a lilliputian edge over the stalwart and experienced Patriots. Butler will not be able to contain Jones.

The Patriots are, for the most part, the superior team in this match up.  However, the Falcons have demonstrated an ability to succeed on offense - in the 2016 regular season their average points per game was 33.8 compared to the Patriots who only put up 27.6.  This is not the only factor that wins games - defense is an important part.  In this aspect, the Patriots far surpassed the Falcons (15.6 ppg let up to 25.4 respectively).  This, no doubt, let the Patriots record be one of the best in the league, 14-2.  Compare this to the Falcons' record of 11-5 and the importance of a good defense cannot be understated.  Going into the Superbowl, the ability to shut down the opposing offense is going to be of utmost importance for both teams, and the Patriots have the edge here.   Experience must be factored into this as well; the duo of Tom Brady and Bill Belichick have won four Super Bowls together.  The largest detractor for the Patriots is the loss of their number one TE, Robert Gronkowski who averaged 16.3 yards per game, 4.5 receptions per game and 0.7 touchdowns per game in the 2015 season.  This may hurt the Patriots, which is why I have opted to have the odds as close as they are.
Pats have an overrated D. Ryan's O, maybe the best ever, will torch it. And no, this isn't just me looking for revenge for my Steelers.
538, other sources. Games like this are very close.
